author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello pumpkiin - There appear to be at least two things going on at once here, and the lesser one is the palpitation issue. When a paitent presents with a primary complaint of palpitations and a low potassium level the doctor is going to want to correct the potassium deficiency and keep it at around 4.0, which you have succeeded in doing. If the palpitations then continue, they can most likely be considered normal or at least secondary to an underlying cause. We all have some premature beats from time to time and some of us have them nearly all the time. If the potassium issue is resolved then palpitations lose some of their initial importance. Since you have been suffering from loose stools and frequent urination among your other symptoms, these were the likely route of potassium loss to begin with. If these symptoms have continued since, the excess molitlity in your lower GI tract could be causing the continued palpaitions. This is not, in itself, a cause for concern, and is common. However, it is not normal to have loose stools, excessive urination, joint aches and pains and lethargy for months at a time, and that is the real issue of concern now that the potassium issue has been managed.   There are any number of conditions which could be causing your ongoing discomfort, and it would require a thorough exam and some additional testing to hopefully figure out what it is. It could be anything from a persistent enterovirus to mononucleosis to chronic fatigue sydrome to acute hepatitis type C, to name just a few, from the less serious to the moreso.   Whatever is going on needs to be addressed, and that can only be accomplished via a comprehensive workup by a general practitioner or internist. Meanwhile, don't discontinue the potassium supplements so long as the other symptoms are present.  Hopefully this is something fairly simple that will run its course, but it would be helpful to at least have it treated symptomatically so that you could feel better. Absolutely do not give up on resolving this!  Good luck to you and do stay in touch.

content: Lamisil is known to increase blood levels of flecainide.  Generally when Lamisil is needed, the flecainide dose can be decreased. author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Your husband's condition is a little concerning.  Often, atrial flutter is not a serious issue.  Blood thinners are recommended (warfarin) to prevent clots from forming in the atria that are not contracting normally.  In your husband's case, it appears that he has a component termed rapid ventricular response.  In this condition the signals for the atrial flutter are being transmitted and causing the ventricles to fire as well.  This rapid ventricular rate wears on the muscle, resulting ultimately in heart failure.  The rapid beating can also interfere with proper blood filling of the heart causing reduced blood circulation.  This is likely the cause of your husband's passing out.  His echocardiogram results indicate a mild amount of heart failure (most likely interpretation).    The pacemaker will help keep his heart from beating too slow; however, it does nothing for rapid heart rates.  There are devices that can be implanted to cardiovert when a particular rhythm occurs.  Your husband may need one of these.  An ablation will likely help stop the ventricles from responding to the atrial fluter and help resolve his problems with racing heart beats.    I am unfamiliar with New Zealand's health care process regarding whether or not the procedure can be done sooner.  Follow up with his cardiologist is essential.  There may be other medications that he can use to help control his symptoms as well.  Best wishes.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Donna, The heart is actually two pumps in one:   the upper called the atria, and the bottom called the ventricles.  They are supposed to work synergistically with a "general" in the upper one called the Sinus Node calling a cadence, as if it were a marching band: "march March! march MARCH!". When the general gets sick you can have a "sick sinus syndrome", and you end up with more of a Jazz band.  When the band is too slow, the pacemaker your husband has will pick up the pace and make the heart beat more effective. When the band goes too fast, he can pass out because there is not enough passive fill of the ventricles from the crippled atria to feed the brain and other organs.  The following link has a good general map of the important aspects of the heart you are concerned about.       http://www.medterms.com/script/main/art ... lekey=2407 Also: the reason your husband is on coumadin is to inhibit the formation of blood clots that can occur in the atria during dysrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter. Consider an eddy attached to a brook, and visualize a leaf floating in it around and around until a poof of wind causes it to join the mainstream.  An atrial dysrhythmia can cause a similar "eddy" and cause the blood that stalls and goes "round and round" to become a clot. Then this clot can suddenly join the mainstream blood flow and travel to the brain or heart or kidneys - anywhere!  It would be wise if your husband limits his activity and stress until you both and his doctor together determine the best course of treatment for him.   FYI:  LV=left ventricle, PPM=permanent pacemaker, MR=mitral regurgitation, LA=left atrium, RV=right ventricle. As the good doctor said, I am also not acquainted with your country's healthcare process.  Please continue to coordinate his care with his primary physician and heart specialist.

content: Dear Suze,  In addition to what the good doctor stated in the previous post I would like to share some observations I have made over the years. You did not mention what kind of digestive supplement you are taking. Some seemingly innocuous OTC (over the counter) supplements known as nutraceuticals may inadvertently contribute to potential problems. A nutraceutical is not evaluated nor listed as either approved or disapproved by the FDA. It is a classification by itself and usually refers to an ingestible or topical substance that has some sort of "natural" effect on human health. If the digestive supplement you are taking causes you to have more stools than normal, it is possible that it can impact your natural chemistry. Potassium is a very important metal in your body, it is particularly valuable to heart health. There are some conditions of the heart that are noticeably impacted by too much or too little potassium (and other minerals also such as sodium, magnesium, calcium, etc.) These levels can be impacted by our lifestyle, diet habits, and other "medicines" we may take.   Dr. Mokhtar recommended you see your doctor and I agree. You may wish to also consider getting lab work done which will easily tell if your chemistry is normal.  I would also suggest you use some introspection, and see if you may be having some unusually stressful situations in your life right now that may be causing you some anxiety. This too can cause the feelings you describe.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Dear xkatiex - You actually sound very normal. Those "missing" beats are actually premature ones and almost everyone has them at some time or another. Some people have them almost constantly. They are a very common source of anxiety and worry, but they also can be caused by anxiety and worry, so it's a difficult cycle to break.   The premature beats are rarely, if ever, diagnostic of anything, but they can cause an awful lot of concern for the person having them. A conscious effort to ignore them only helps to focus attention on them, so it is an ironic problem. The best thing is to allow yourself to become absorbed in something else and with luck you won't notice them as much. Oddly, some people have hundreds per day but don't feel them, while other people only have a very few, but feel every one.   The chest pain has been diagnosed as Tietz' Syndrome, so that is fine. It may respond to a low dose of something like Tylenol, but is not cardiac related at all, and since you are active and a dancer, you probably put your upper body through more contortions than you realize, which can cause or aggravate that problem. Any chest pain that is worsened by movement or pressing with your finger is not heart-related. So you can let that one go. It will usually resolve on its own, but if not, then taking it easy on the affected body part may help.   The Holter monitor (24 hour EKG you mentioned) should give you a lot of peace of mind once it becomes available for you to use.   You didn't mention how tall you are or your weight, nor did you happen to mention how fast your heart rate was at the hospital, but some sinus (normal) tachycardia is normal for young females, especially if they are hyper to begin with, and moreso if they are petite or thin. The fact that you acknowlege being stress-prone and a worrier also plays into that.   You sound like a normal, healthy young woman who is tuned in to her body perhaps a little more than you need to be. It's hard not to once you've become aware of your own heart's beating, but again, do try and let yourself be distracted by other, more enjoyable things. And do update us when you finally get to have to 24 hour EKG.

content: Hello - At your age it's not unusual to get lightheaded on standing up, but it shouldn't happen all the time. Did this happen in conjunction with the skipped beats? Sometimes you can get every other beat being a premature beat and that can cause some people to feel lightheaded briefly, but most of the time it's due to having been seated or lying down for a while then getting up and it takes a second or two for your heart to realize you've changed position. The blood needs to stay in your head to stay conscious, and when you stand, especially in your age group when the body is still adjusting to its size or you're still growing, you can sometimes take your heart by surprise by getting up too quickly and it has to beat harder and faster to keep the blood up there in your brain so you don't fall down. If it happens real often it's worth looking into, but it's pretty normal if it just  happens on occasion.   Hope this helps.

content: Hello The Saint - FIrst  of all, as you've probably noticed here on the forum, you are in very good company. There are a lot of people with benign PVCs and other sorts of blips and ireeguarities who are also concerned about them. The up side of that is that, as you've already read here, these things are virtually never a matter of medical concern. They can, however, be of major emotional significance. I suspect most people who become aware of their hearts' behavior, especially when there is an occasional misfire, feel the same concerns you have expressed in your post.  Here's the thing about SCD: usually those conditions which predispose to it are easily detected, provided an individual with reason to be concerned brings this concern to the attention of his doctor. There is usually some  telling family history (often very remarkable), and there are almost always very clear markers for those at risk for SCD. You (and your doctor) appear to have done  everything reasonable to rule out any risk of SCD.   Again, please bear in mind that just about everyone has at least an occasional PVC or PAC. Some people have huge numbers of them (I mean like thousands in a 24 hour period) and being otherwise healthy and  without any markers  for risk of SCD, have no medical cause for concern.  I repeat, we all have some, and some have many.   As a person who was heavy ("stout" might be the word that applies here) and athletic as well, it was wise  for you to have yourself screened for any potential problems, as those with certain  structural abnormalities can increase the severity of them by their athletic conditioning. Not every "stout" athlete, obviously,  has a problem - a few do here and there - and you clearly are not one of them. For athletes, even those who are not "stout", it is wise to have a one-time screening (with EKG and echocardiogram) just to be certain there is nothing funny going on inside. Youve done that.   There are some electrical problems that are also very commonly genetic (inheriited) and there is usually some family history. These are readily picked up on a single 12-lead EKG.   You defiinitely have, with your cardiologist's careful workup, ruled out any prone-ness to SCD. The possibility, having done that, becomes,  for you, virtually nil.   While you have zero risk factors for SCD,  and only the usual oes (male, "stout") for  future coronary artery disease (whcih can  be headed off in part by having your cholesterol checked and  kept in line if necessary), making you a very fortunate person, you also have a negative family history,  in that there  is  no premature heart disease evident, and people are living into their 80's (with the exception of your grandmother, who still lived a pretty long time considering she   was diabetic). This  is actually considered a protective trait.   Based on the information you've provided about your own health and your family history, you would be classified as at no risk for SCD, and low-risk for coronary artery disease. You are truly a  specimen!   What you do have working against you is anxiety and your own awareness of your body, which is not only a very common thing but in your case has some  medical basis, since you've been through a pretty scary non-cardiac event and come out the other side! Congratulations on  having beat the cancer and  as for your heart, you really are among the  chosen few who can  rest  easy and are at the very bottom of the risk ladder.   I hope this helps  put your mind at ease. There are definite markers  for SCD and you didn't have any! Something else to celebrate!

content: What you are describing is almost a text book presentation of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).  Heart rates that suddenly jump to a speed of 180 or more (as if a light switch had been flipped) then just as suddenly jump back down to normal are very suspicious of SVT.  I would recommend that you discuss this with your doctor.  SVT can be a little difficult to diagnose with EKG's because inbetween events the heart may be normal.  You may benefit from a holter monitor if the events are happening fairly regularly or an event monitor if the events are more rare.  A holter monitor may help elicit the etiology of your "missed beats" also.  Hope this helps.  Keep us updated.

title: [no title]
content: Hi catamaran - While waiting for Dr. Lowe's response I think I can answer this for you. In an otherwise young and healthy person SVT (which is very likely what you experienced) is not life-threatening. It can be very disruptive, however, and once documented, can be treated and/or elimiinated.   In the meantime, until the diagnosis has been made definite via a recording device, it would probably be wise to cease vigorous activity during an episode (and your natural impulse would likely be to stop). This is usually a self-limiting arrhythmia, and it generally causes people to stop what they're doing or at least slow down. Since the heart is already going just about as fast as it theoretically is able, you won't put it into overdrive, but vigorous activity, if it still seems feasible, could build up an oxygen debt which might cause you to faint and injure yourself. That's about the only risk involved with SVT.   The prudent thing would be to first determine for certain the arrhythmia is SVT (I'd put money on it, but that's not how medicine is practiced), learn to manage it or begin a course of treatment to control or eliiminate it, and then resume life as per usual.   Please do stay in touch!

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hi borninlbc - The short answer to your question is an unqualified yes. The fact that it can, and often does, is in itself not important unless the palpitations are bothersome, in which case one could simply take a pass on the alcohol.   However, there is a different phenomenon that can occur at times. When a person drinks more, or more often, than usual (as often takes place during the holidays in the US) some people find themselves with an abnormal rhythm called atrial fibrillation. This is usually temporary, resolving on its own (the phenomenon has come to be referred to as "holiday heart" in some circles) but if it doesn't self-correct very quickly, it should be brought to the attention of a doctor, as atrial fibrillation, while not dangerous in its own right, can permit the formation of clots in the upper chambers of the heart, which then can be discharged into the bloodstream, reach the brain, block a vessel there and cause a stroke.   Most people who drink occasionally rarely, if ever, have this happen. Chronic abusers of alcohol often do.   If you or someone you know experiences occasional "flip flops" or "skips" during or after consumption of moderate amounts of alcohol, this is not a cause for concern. If one experiences a sustained (for hours or days) fluttering or full sensation in the chest,  it is worth looking into. But most drinkers will experience occasional premature beats as a result of even light alcohol consumption.   Hope this helps.

content: Hello creg - You do seem to have a lot going on, and it is not unreasonable to feel some anxiety or at least concern about symptoms which limit one's activity or disrupt life, even if only on occasion. That being said, it is difficult, especially in matters such as you have described, to separate heart and head. We all have very visceral and emotional responses to misbehavior of the heart. It's almost impossible to avoid. The trick is in finding out just what is going on and then learn to cope with it if it is, indeed, benign.   Some of the things you've described could definitely be caused by hemolytic anemia, but then it would be essential to find the underlying cause (if there is one - sometimes the disease is what is known as "essential", that is, exists for no other reason but usually there is one) and work to correct it. That would normally involve taking folic acid and possibly steroids. In fact, the dramatic episodes you describe do sound like hemolytic crises, so I'm puzzled as to why nothing more has been done to rule that in/out and possibly treat it.  All anemias can also cause more than the occasional premature heartbeats (PVCs), so this also plays into the HA possibility.  The problem is that whatever you're feeling, the feelings are real, and they are rarely only in someone's head. The real question is: Are they significant or not? While the premature beats are not, the rest may well be. The premature beats will, however, bring the head into the game and can cause significant anxiety. In this case that may be a good thing, as it is forcing you to bring the whole bag of symptoms to the attention of doctors. It's important that the low hemoglobin count be accounted for, and simply telling you that "ladies at [your] age can feel like this" is hardly the kind of reasurrance you're looking for right now.   It sounds as though you'll need to be persistent in order to get to the bottom of this. If the pills they gave you helped they perhaps were folic acid and/or B6?   Premature heartbeats are virtually always benign, but they can cause anxiety and they can increase in frequency during periods of anemia. Given that your hemoglobin levels have been low enough to warrant some sort of treatment, further exploration is in order so that you can feel better and be truly reassured. Keep after them for answers, and please do keep us updated.

content: Hi creg - You are quite welcome. It sounds like the folic acid is doing its job, and you have gotten reassuring results back from all the heart tests. As to your question about prolonged anemia causing your heart to become irritable, well, no, not really. Once the situation is corrected there's rarely any damage to the muscle. However, for a lot of people, once PVCs have started, it's like the heart has learned a new "trick" and wants to do it some more. Whatever triggers them to begin with (and the list of possible triggers is longer than you'd want to try and read here) seems to open the door and it really doesn't mean much in terms of the health of the heart, but it can cause quite a bit of consternation in the person having them, which of course liberates a certain amount of adrenaline in response to the stress or anxiety, and that is one of those triggers. So in time it will probably settle down.   Taken by themselves, PVCs have very little medical significance. However, by their very nature they make us nervous, so that often is all it takes to make them happen more. It's a real feat trying not to think about a thing - usually brings our mind right to focus on the thing we're trying to not think about - so the best approach is to just accept the benign nature of them and try your best to ignore them. There are medications that can make them less frequent, but if there's a possibility of hypothyroidism you might not want to try one of those until that is ruled out, as the most commonly-prescribed class of drugs can exacerbate some of the symptoms of hypothyroid. By the same token, synthetic thyroid, if that becomes an issue, can sometimes also cause premature beats, although if regulated correctly this should be a minimal issue at best.  Your observation that palpitations often seem to increase just prior to (and sometimes during) a woman's period is correct, too. Just one more of the hundred-odd things that can set them off.   Please do let us know what comes of the next doctor visit, and good luck to you!

title: [no title]
content: Abrupt onset of a rapid heart rate followed by an almost as abrupt end can often be the sign of a heart dysrhythmia known as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).    If the episodes are few and far between it can be difficult to diagnose SVT.  Diagnosis hinges on "catching" one of the episodes on paper.  To accomplish this, many cardiologists will first do an EKG.  This may show some predisposing signs to SVT, such as the presence of a syndrome called Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome.  If the EKG is normal, you can be set up with a holter monitor that is a 24-72 hour continuous recording EKG.  If the episodes are not that predictable an event recorder can be used.  With this device you press a button when you feel the symptoms and it records the EKG for the recent time period.  The advantage to this is that it can be worn for longer periods of time.  Talking with your doctor is the first step.  Hope this helps.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Dear gettingfedup - Your screen name says it all. This sort of thing can be very frustrating. A big part of the problem is a failure of the doctor to explain clearly to the patient what is going on and why he is not concerned about it. Now you have seen five doctors about this problem, three of them cardiologists, and yet you are not on any medication. Clearly no one has found anything they feel is life-threatening, but just as clearly, no one has explained, to your satisfaction, what is going on and why.   You mention that the "episode" going on when you placed your post had been going on for three hours. We need to get clear on what you percieve as an episode. One can have an arrhythmia that is non-stop, rapid or regularly irregular, for hours. However, if you are having, instead, frequent premature beats, this would not be considered a single episode, but rather an "interlude" during which you experienced a great many premature beats but not a treatable rapid or irregular heartbeat. I know, it can be confusing, because having premature beats (either premature atrial or ventricular contractions) is technically an "irregular" heart rhythm, but it is made up of a collection of frequent but individual beats. I suspect this is what is happening, and is why no one has expressed concern. The fact is, almost all premature heartbeats, no matter how frequent they are (unless they become strung together into a sustained, rapid tachyarrhythmia), are benign and doctors would prefer to not treat them. However, if they are causing acute anxiety and unnecessary worry to the extent that they are affecting one's ability to function and enjoy life, then a doctor may prescribe a beta blocker to reduce the frequency of the "bips."  You've had virtually every appropriate diagnostic procedure, yet it appears no one has explained the problem iin a way that makes you comfortable. This shouldn't be that difficult.  One thing you said which makes the frequent premature beat scenario all the more likely is that it almost always happens when you are not active. This is extremely common with Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs) and they tend to go away when one gets up and starts moving around. Also, despite what I said about continuous arrhythmias, as always there is the exception which proves the rule, and you may be experiencing what is called bigemeny, which is quite common and does form a sort of "episode" at times - can go on for hours or days, even - and yet is really every other beat being a premature one, and is not technically a true arrhythmia, at least not in the strict sense. Bigemeny, when in the form of PVCs, tends to perpetuate itself, especially when the subject is sitting relatively still. Every other beat is premature, and this often can cause painful sensations, especially when the premature beat occurs while the tricuspid valve of the heart happens to be closed.   The fact that there is a history of heart disease on both sides of your family is good reason to be concerned and to see a doctor about the problem; However, PVCs are almost never diagnostically significant. Once they start, if the patient is sufficiently aware of them, this causes anticipatory anxiety which can, in and of itself, trigger yet more premature beats. It becomes a cycle that is ever more worrisome for the patient and frustrating for the doctor.   You mentioned that some of your EKGs have shown some "damage" to your heart while others do not. True heart muscle damage does not go away (for instance, if one has had a heart attack the scar and the attendant EKG changes do not disappear, although they do change with time, up to a certain point - then they remain the same). On the other hand, most EKG machines which are programmed to interpret the tracings will occasionally misread or misinterpret abnormalities or "see" things that aren't there, which is why a doctor must read the tracings and decide whether the finding is "true" or not. (By the way, this occurs more frequently in women than in men).  If there were any definite damage to your heart muscle someone would by now have told you, suggested a course of treatment or management, and you would definitely be on some form of medication.   I strongly suspect you are one of the many people who, when quiet, start to have PVCs, perhaps in a group pattern, which can go on for hours and feel very disturbing. Again, these are almost always benign, so the challenge is how to break the cycle, to reduce the frequency of the ectopic beats and/or to reduce the patient's concern. I have to fault at least one of the doctors you've seen for not taking the time to explain the problem and offer some palliative agent such as a beta blocker or anti-anxiety agent.   You sound like a healthy young woman with a "normal" abnormality which really troubles you when you are aware of it. It is a very common complaint, and there are things that can sometimes help make it less troublesome. I would narrow the field down  to one doctor you feel most comfortable with and ask if he or she can offer something more than a rerun of the tests you've already had. A sympathetic ear can sometimes work wonders.  I hope this has been of some help and reassurance to you. Please keep us updated.

content: Dear Stevie13Wonder - A few definitions may be helpful. First, when medical people refer to "extra" beats they actually mean "extra" in the sense of a place of origin outside the normal pathway (as in "external" and not "additional" beats). This is a fine distinction but is helpful to know because these "extra" or premature beats are almost always followed by a pause that compensates for their prematurity, and  so helps to maintain the normal underlying rhythm.   I believe you may have posted about your child in another thread, as I recall discussing Long QT in a nine year old with a family history. There was mention that time  of  a possible junctional  escape  rhythm. While p-waves are rarely seen in junctional complexes, if they are present at all they usually will show up in the wrong place, as you describe, suggesting  a dissociation between the sinus node and the pathway below it.    I think it would help avoid confusion if we could keep this all in the oriiginal thread, so that there is continuity of the  exchange of information. I hope you will let us know when the adrenaline  challenge test has been done and what the findings are, but please post it in your original thread so we don't lose track of you. content: Hi again stevie13wonder - No need to apologize. It just helps keep track of a given issue when the questions are in a row.   As far as the R-on-T phenomenon, it is a matter of some controversy now and again, because it is usually only a concern in adults who have had a heart attack, and even then many studies have found that more of those patients have serious problems who have not previously had this oddity show up. It may be unusual in a nine-year-old, and it's worth a second opinon (which your doctor is seeking) but it may not actually be of much diagnostic significance.   I certainly understand and appreciate your concern, and your questions are more than welcome. I would think that if Long Q-T is suspected the doctors would want to rule it in or out as soon as possible. In the meantime the best thing (especially in case either boy does have this disorder) is to try and maintain a relaxed and positive outlook, as hard as that may be, because stress is one of the things that can trigger an episode. Also, since the diagnosis may well rest on the outcome of the adrenaliine challenge, it may be a good idea to subtly encourage both boys to refrain from competitive sports for the time being.   It's very difficult to maintain a calm exterior when one's children are at possible risk, but in this case it could actually be therapeutic.  Please do keep us updated and bring up any other questions or issues you may think of.  Good luck to you.

content: Hello Steve - I am wondering what caused your son to initially be brought in for LQT testing. Did he have any fainting episodes or other symptoms suggestive of LQT? Is there a family history of LQT or deafness? These things are very important factors in sorting out this sort of problem so that it can be treated appropriately.  The fact that your son exhibited a junctional rhythm upon standing and hyperventilating is odd for a person with LQT, but of course not unheard of. It seems more likely to suggest a blocking of some portion of the conduction pathway or an abnormal slowing (as in what is known as vagotonia, an inappropriate slowing of the heart by the vagus nerve as in dysautonomia). These conditions are generally less worrisome than Long QT, but still would need to be addressed. And of course, if there is a family history of LQT, then all this could simply be prelude to a more complete presentation of LQT symptoms (usually fainting upon being startled by a loud noise, during stress, etc.). This sounds, based on what you've reported, as though the AV junction is temporarily taking over the pacemaking duties because of an imappropriately slowed sinus rhythm. The fact that it may be cutting the rate in half sounds like there could actually be some sort of intermittent block, but I am thinking vagal stimulation is more likely because it occurred upon standing and with hyperventiilation, two things which can stimulate an overly sensitive vagus nerve.   Your son might have some variant condition that could cause symptoms similar to LQT, which would be a more benign diagnosis, although Long QT is treatable. It needs to be very accurately diagnosed, however, in order to treat it effectively. If the problem is vagotonia instead, there are different therapeutic approaches.   I am not familiar with a direct correlation between a junctional rhythm and TdP, although there can be an indirect relationship. TdP is the usual arrhythmia seen in LQT patients. A junctional escape rhythm is a backup system built in to take over for a too slow heart rate resulting from vagal stimulation or one of the higher degree heart blocks. Symptoms of either of these and LQT can be similar, but the causes really quite different.   I hope you get a concrete answer soon, so that you can relax and know that the problem will receive the appropriate treatment.   I hope this is helpful.

content: Hello again - With that family history it seems rather likely your child does have evolving Long QT syndrome. The junctional escape rhythm probably has been  functoining as a backup during loss of normal ventricular stimulation. Also, families with a history  of electric derangement of the heart's conduction system can have variations and/or additional abnormalities.   The episode your 19 year old experienced may well have been  the equivalent of an adrenaline challenge as the combination of natural adrenaline (released during an  athletic activity) plus the ventolin, which is powerful medicatoin similar in effect to adrenaline. The doctor who observed that the long QT interval at the time was probably caused by the ventolin seems to have missed the greater point that anyone predisposed to Long QT is likely to have it increased by use of any epinepherine-like  drug. Long QT, as you probably know, can be intermittent and can also be acquired (usually due to use of certain medications).   Use of beta blockers is often recommended therapeutically for confirmed LQT, and can provide a fair degree of protection.  There are also implantable devices available for appropriate subjects. The important thing is that this condition can usually be managed, although sometimes some lifestyle changes have to be made as well.  It seems you are now in  good hands with the new doctor,  who appears to be doing all the necessary and appropriate things.  I wish you and yours all the  best.  Please keep us updated.

title: [no title]
content: Hello capricekid -  PVCs are one of the most common chronic complaints, and one which can cause severe anxiety in otherwise healthy patients, leading to many more ER visits and testing than would otherwise normally be done. They are rarely serious and almost never of any diagnostic significance. They are rarely treated unless they are causing the patient severe emotional distress, which is often the case. They can accompany any form of heart disease but also occur commonly in totally normal hearts. The list of potential benign causes is so long it would be impractical to go over them all here, but a few of the most common might be helpful:  - Mitral Valve Prolapse (usually benign and often an equivocal findingl) - electrolyte imbalance (most often too little potassium, although   sometimes too much as well) - anxiety - stress - sleep disturbance -caffeine - nicotine  In some cases the use of a beta blocker, the treatment of choice in most instances, can actually serve to produce more PVCs, as this type of drug slows the heart rate, and that is often the reason for the PVCs in the first place (in healthy patients activity will often make PVCs go away, while rest slows the heart rate and they come back again). Still, beta blockers are the safest and most effective medication for otherwise benign PVCs.  Now then: you mention that you were told by a tech after your recent stress test that you had some S-T abnormalities,  especially near the end of the test. This is unfortunate, and it is why many doctors encourage their staff to keep such well-intended observations to themselves. It often causes far more anxiety in the patient rather than reassuring them. S-T and T-wave abnormalities are very common in healthy people for a variety of reasons, although of course they also can be suggestive of a problem, depending on the context as interpreted by the attending physician. In this case the physician seemed unconcerned and you do have a follow up scheduled, so any dangling questions can be addressed at that time. Of course if you should have any new symptoms in the meantime you should notify your doctor or, if they are severe, get yourself to the nearest emergency department. This is generic advice for anyone, and not based on any information you have supplied in your post.   It is worth noting that while you did not reach your maximal  heart rate during the stress test, you only missed it by 3 beats. This is a very good showing for someone taking Atenolol, and should be considered an adequate rate to make the test a success.  PVCs do occur in nearly everyone, and in some they are extremely frequent while in others they are either infrequent or for some mysterious reason they are not noticed by the subject.   It sounds as though you're in good shape, but once you've had a chance to press the doctor about the tech's comment you will likely feel a lot better.  Good luck to you!

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello chalotta1980: I think it is safe to say that PVCs and the vagus nerve are almost a hand-in-hand affair. While some PVCs are caused by direct irritation of the heart muscle or by medications, they are also very frequently the result of what is known as the "vagus effect", which takes place when the vagus nerve is stimulated by any one of a number of things. Since the vagus nerve is not only responsible for slowing the heart rate but also with promoting peristalsis (the churning action of the stomach and intestines to assist in digestion) it is very common for people to experience PVCs after having eaten. There is also the natural slowing of the body's metabolism at day's end, with slowing of the heart rate, and so at bedtime there are also more PVCs noted in many people. This is all very normal.   In addition, since you are diagnosed with acid reflux, there is the potential for a bolus of food and/or stomach acid to work its way up into your esophagus after having eaten, and this bolus can produce PVCs in two ways as well: one, by causing pressure on the vagus nerve, which runs down the neck alongside the esophagus, and also by being accompanied by bloating that can actually press against the heart and "tickle" it, again provoking PVCs. All of this is perfectly normal and benign (although acid reflux ought not be seen as "normal" and should be treated to prevent the symptoms as well as potential damage to the lining of the esophagus). A large proportion of people experience PVCs after having eaten, even if they don't suffer from acid reflux. Anything that stimulates the vagus nerve will put a "braking effect" on the heart rate, and that will usually provoke at least some PVCs.   It's annoying, but in and of itself it is fairly normal and benign. I hope this is helpful to you.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello ecoli: From the sound of your symptoms you probably are having two different things go on at once, which is causing some confusion and anxiety for you. The pains you describe do sound like an inflammatory process and not like cardiac pain, which almost always will show up deep in the center of the chest and radiate to one or both shoulders, arms, and even the little finger, as well as up into the neck and lower jaw.  However, even for atypical cardiac pain, what you describe seems rather like something else, as atypical pain almost always occurs in some points along the pathway described above, ie: in the left (or both) shoulders, one or both elbows, wrists, the neck or the jaw. It may also show up in the center of the upper back. Yours seems to be popping up in rather random locations. However, the severity of any suspect chest pain should not be the measure of its importance, but rather where it occurs and what else is going on at the same time. For instance, does movement, such as twisting of your upper body, reaching, bending, etc., evoke the pain? Is the pain aggravated by exertion or does it occur at rest? The answers to these questions can help determine what sort of pain you are having. It sounds like your doctor got the pain diagnosis right off the bat.   The fluttering sensation in your chest is probably Premature Atrial or Ventricular Contractions (PACs and PVCs). These are quite normal and common with or without heart disease, and can be provoked or aggravated by caffeine, nicotine, anxiety, stress, sleep deprivation, inhalation of noxious fumes, etc. The list is quite long, and sometimes there is no apparent reason for them.   It doesn't appear that the chest pain and the fluttering sensation (palpitations) are likely to be related. However, only a medical doctor can make certain of this, so if you are made uneasy by the fluttering it would make sense to visit your doctor and bring this matter up to him. A resting EKG and perhaps a 24-hour Holter monitor study could rule out anything out of the ordinary and help you to feel more relaxed about the sensations.

content: Dear Searching: While your symptoms are syfficiently vague to lead to a presumptive conclusion of anxiety as the root cause, there are two other factors that could be causing your symptoms. One is innocent and normal. The other warrants a closer look.   The "innocent" factor is bedtime palpitations, which are caused by the same mechanism as "after dinner" palpitations: a slowing of the heart due to natural fatigue and/or stimulation of the vagus nerve by digestion. This is quite normal.   The one that warrants a closer look is your positive family history for coronary artery disease. While premature beats, the usual cause of palpitations, are not diagnostic of heart disease at all, the fact that they brought you in to the doctor's office and caused you to disclose a positive family history, normally would be enough to warrant a cardiac consult to rule out any possible coronary artery disease. The simplest way to do this would be for your doctor to refer you for a nuclear scan stress test and echocardiogram. If these are all normal (as is likely) then you could feel safe in trying to ignore the palpitations or learn to live with them.   As your doctor has duly noted, there is a basis for suspecting many of your symptoms are caused by anxiety, and that has been treated. If your symptoms continue to make you uncomfortable then the real issue should be addressed by ruling out any possibility of coronary artery disease. My instincts suggest this to be a combination of normal ectopic heartbeats and some attendant anxiety, but I also feel it would be helpful to you to have active heart disease ruled out, something I would suggest to anyone with a strong postive family history. Good luck to you!

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Dear jfrank8028: You have already gotten a very good reply from Aeron12. I would only add a few observations, as what you describe is actually a rather common complaint. There is a suspicion that most of the time when we lie down we are ready to go to sleep, and so are feeling tired. The body is wanting to slow down, and lying down changes the demands on the heart rather abruptly. Lying on one's left side or back places the heart into closer proximity with skeletal structures which, in some individuals, can result in some actual physical contact between the heart and chest wall. Since most hearts are easily "annoyed" by touching, and since the heart is having the "brakes put on" by sleepiness and the change in posture already (due to stimulation of the vagus nerve which slows heart rate as well as causing peristalsis - stomach and intestinal churning), it's not surprising that this would be a common occurrence and so a common complaint. Not everyone is equally aware of their heart's behavior, and not everyone is affected this way, but an awfully large number of people are. So although it is likely unnerving and annoying it really isn't unusual nor is it likely a cause for concern.   As Aeron12 points out, what you are likely feeling are Premature Ventricular Contractions (the most common heart irregularity and one which normally occurs with slowing of the rate). They can occur at random intervals but a lot of people also experience what's known as "group beating" - a regular beat followed by a premature one - which is known as bigemeny. (If there are two regular beats then an early one, repeatedly, then it is called trigemeny, and so on). There's nothing inherently wrong with this, but if one can feel it then it draws attention to itself and can cause unease.  PVCs can occur at rest (most often) or during exercise. When they occur at rest they frequently will disappear upon exertion, and vice versa, because they are primarily a function of the heart's slowing. They are not diagnostic of anything, and are rarely of any clinical significance, but that doesn't mean they can't make you feel awfully uncomfortable. Reassurance, and sometimes a beta blocker, can reduce the frequency, although there are instances where the beta blocker's slowing of the heart rate can actually encourage them.   You said you were origninally placed on a beta blocker because your resting heart rate was 90, which is actually considered the upper limit of normal, especially if you are petite. (The smaller a person is, the more likely the resting rate will tend toward the faster end of the scale).   You also mention that your mother has Mitral Valve Prolapse, and this often is a familial trait. People with MVP often have more frequent and varied heartbeat irregularities, usually of no real consequence except the emotional harm that can be incurred by worrying that something is wrong with the heart. Whether or not your doctor decides to prescribe a Holter monitor to discover the true frequency of your premature beats (not a bad way to get a little peace of mind), you might want to have MVP ruled out by means of an echocardiogram, since there is a family history. MVP is usually considered quite benign also, but knowing what's going on generally helps people cope better with the annoying symptoms it can cause.   By the way, sudden withdrawal of beta blocker (Atenolol in this case) could provoke additional premature beats and other annoying symptoms. One should always be weaned off beta blockers rather than stopping them abruptly. This may explain why you're noticing more premature beats now.   In short, while there is a possible familial trait, it is not usually a serious one, but can cause enough vague and random symptoms that it would be worth knowing about. Other than that you sound like a very healthy young woman.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Your complaint is not an unusual one. There are probably several possible explanations for what's going on, but first I would encourage you to be persistent with your doctor until you feel you've been heard and have some peace of mind, since when our hearts misbehave we feel them quite acutely and the healthcare provider does not, even if he or she may have experienced something similar. Many cases are similar but the experience is always unique.  That being said, first of all it is very common, following an AVNRT ablation, for the patient to have some intermittent episodes of junctional tachycardia afterward. This does not feel quite the same as the original problem, but it can be uncomfortable. It is because the A/V node has been "worked on" and sometimes remains irritable for a while. This usually passes in a short time. If it doesn't, although it is not dangerous, it needs at the very least a good talking-through. Also, it is not unheard of for one who has had such an ablation to have to return for a "fine tuning" of the work, as some miniscule fibers sometimes can remain in place to allow the "short circuit" to occasionally fire.   The likely reason your cardiologist seems so certain that your current rapid heart rate is "normal" (sinus tach) is likely because that is what he sees on your resting EKG or Holter monitor tracings. There is a significant difference in the waveforms of "normal" accellerated heart rate, and you describe certain symptoms from both before and after the ablation that suggest, not unreasonably, that you may have some underlying anxiety that is causing your heart to speed up now. Feeling uncertain about what is going on with one's heart is a very common cause of acute anxiety, and even a totally normal heart will react to the release of adrenaline caused by anxiety, by speeding up. The fact that you experience shaking and fatigue also strongly suggest anxiety. No one wants to hear that explanation, and it should never be given carelessly. Your doctor needs to reassure you in a way that you can take home with you feeling good about his responses. This can be very difficult, especially when anxiety complicates the picture, but it is part of a doctor's responsibility, to treat the whole patient and make sure he is fine emotionally as well as physically.   Hopefully these thoughts of mine will help you to communicate your concerns to your doctor and also to reassure you that you're sounding pretty normal given what you've experienced so far. Good luck to you!

content: Hello,  Palpitations are what experienced as unpleasant awareness of own heartbeats. They may be felt in the chest, throat, or neck.  You may feel it as skipped or stopped beats. An unusually slow heart rate is called bradycardia, and an occasional extra heart beat is called extrasystole.   Common causes include: - Exercise  - Anxiety, stress, fear  - Caffeine, nicotine, cocaine, diet pills  - Overactive thyroid  - Anemia  and decrease O2 supply to tissues.ow levels of oxygen in your blood  -Fever  -Mitral valve prolapse and other heart disease   -Medications such as beta blockers for high blood pressure or heart disease, or anti-arrhythmics. author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: The beats that you describe as a flutter are likely premature ventricular contractions (PVC's).  These occur when the bottom pumping chambers decide to beat on their own rather than in conjuction with the top chambers.  If we were to put a holter monitor on everyone, we'd find that most people have some PVC's.  These are harmless beats.  Often, things like caffeine will "excite" the heart and cause a few more PVC's to occur, much like you describe.  As the heart rate increases, normally the speed of the heart overrides these PVC's and they decrease in frequency.  PVC's that increase with an increasing heart rate may not be normal and should be evaluated.  Ventricular tachycardia is when the ventricals decide to beat on their own for several beats in a row (technically >3 beats).  Essentially it is a series of PVC's one right after another.  Ventricular tachycardia if short may not be noticable, or if prolonged can ultimately lead to fainting and death if not corrected.  The range is quite varied.  If you feel as if you are having runs of these beats I would strongly recommend you be evaluated by a cardiologist.  There are other heart rhythm's that can cause palpitations that should be checked for as well.  One notable syndrome is Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome which can cause a different form of tachycardia.  EKG's should pick these up.  I'm not a cardiologist, so that's about as complex as I can get for you.  As far as other things you can do, cutting down on caffeine will help.  I'd recommend you be evaluated by a cardiologist to get more information about what is going on with your heart.  Hope this helps.

content: Hi angelforever34, When a person experiences PVC's (premature ventricular contractions) the symptom is often described as a missed/skipped beat, or the sensation of a flip-flop of the heart. Several things may contribute to exacerbation of PVC's, for example, caffiene intake, electrolyte distubances, Mitral valve abnormalities etc. If you have not had a cardiac workup in 1 1/2 years along with labwork etc. I would suggest that you inquire about having this completed. author: Dr. R. Perala  Medical Doctor Posts: 12 Joined: Tue Aug 09, 2005 6:02 pm Location: Cave Creek, Arizona  Contact:   Contact Dr. R. Perala       Website
title: PVCs
content: Hi:  These are almost certainly PVCs (premature ventricular contractions), also called VEBs (ventricular ectopic beats).  They are caused by excitabilty in the heart tissue of the ventricles.  Normally, a beat is initiated by the sinus node (at the top of the atria), it passes through the atria causing them to contract, then passes through the AV (atrio-ventricular) node to the ventricles, causing them to contract.  In the case of a PVC, a ventricular cell initiates a beat.  This beat is usually not perceived (skipped beat), but the next beat (which is stronger due to extra ventricular filling) is perceived as a palpitation.   The sensation in the neck is due to the increased blood volume pumped from the heart, and from momentary disruption of the normal wave form of blood flow from the heart.   PVCs are actually a fairly normal occurrence...One study showed that up to 50-60% of healthy people experience occasional PVCs (although they may not feel them). Caffeine, nicotine, stress and cold medicines are common precipitants of PVCs.  I used to experience them pretty frequently in medical school, when I was drinking a lot of coffee...I had almost the exact sensation that both of you have experienced...And, if you don't know what it is, it's definitely sanity threatening, even if it isn't life threatening :)   Normally PVCs can just be treated by avoiding excess caffeine, nicotine, alcohol and stress (if possible).  If they are still occuring, a beta-blocker (like propranolol, atenolol or metoprolol) will usually prevent them.  This is the recommended treatment, but certain antiarrhythmic drugs (like Pirmenol) can also be used.  Marleymum, you should have your murmur investigated...Valvular problems can potentiate PVCs.   The best treatment is still a beta-blocker (in your case it will kill two birds with one stone: PVCs and hypertension), but you still need an echo (heart ultrasound) to evaluate your heart valves.  The doctor can then try to adjust your propranolol dosage, or try metoprolol or an antiarrhythmic to eliminate the PVCs.  In the meantime, try to cut back on coffee, tea, pop, alcohol, etc., to see if that reduces the frequency of the PVCs.  Thanks for your question!  -Reid Perala, MD (student doctor

title: [no title]
content: Your doctor is right to be concerned; v-tach is serious.  Ablation is an option, but may have to be repeated.  A device called an ICD (implantable cardioverter defibrillator) can be placed, and will sense if an episode is happening. title: Re: pacs lasting for a couple days
content: Dear pistol81,  Palpitations can be caused by: 1. An overactive thyroid gland. 2. Electrolytes disturbance. 3. Mitral valve prolapse. 4. Smoking. 5. Drinking alcohol. 6. Drinking too much caffeinated beverages. 7. Not getting enough sleep. 8. Stress.  If not already done i would suggest a blood test for thyroid gland and electrolytes.  An echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) is usually to rule out the presence of mitral valve prolapse. Mitral valve prolapse is a fairly common condition found in otherwise healthy young adults who usually complain of palpitations and atypical chest pain. By now i think that you already had your echocardiogram but not sure whether or not you know the results already and whether or not you discussed the results with your cardiologist.  Another test is to have a holter monitor (portable heart monitor) that the patient wears for 24 hours, it will show how extra beats you have and their nature all over the 24 hours which is better than just having an ekg.  Stop smoking if you are, stop drinking alcohol and caffeinated beverages, try to have enough sleep and rest. Stress can cause this kind of symptoms as well. These measures help a lot of patients get rid of their symptoms.  i don't think that you need treatment for the time being. content: Dear Brian,  It is not rare for young healthy individuals to get extra beats from time to time.  Since you already had all the bood tests, i would recommend having two more test. Continue the measures that you are doing. In addition, stop smoking completely, no alcohol whatsoever and get enough rest and sleep. title: Re: Lots of cardiac tests no reason for pains/palpitations
content: Dear Joshua,  You have 2 major risk factors for coronary disease, being a male and having hypertension. Your chest pain is atypical as compared to that of coronary disease. So, the probability that this pain be due to coronary disease i would say is very low to low.  Have you had an echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) to rule out a condition called mitral valve prolapse? This is a condition that is known to cause chest pain and palpitations and just needs to be watched.  In otherwise healthy young people who don't have heart disease, pvcs can be observed safely without worry or treatments. It is not unusual for healthy young people to have pvcs (and no cause is usually found). In the past, all pvcs were treated but not after a major study found that there is nothing to worry about in healthy young individuals without heart disease. You are already being treated for high blood pressure with a medication that should be controlling the pvcs. Did you have a holter while you were on toprol?  The pain that you are describing sounds to me like nerve pain more than anything else, i would recommend that you have an x-ray/ct scan of the neck to evaluate your cervical spine. title: Re: Sinus tach waking me up in the early morning hours
content: Dear Sherie,  Thank you very much for the update.  What do you mean by you being a bleeder?  There are certain arrhythmias that look exactly like sinus tachycardia and they are actually are not and they can be detected except by an electrophysiologic study, so an electrophysiologic study is actually not a bad idea.  As for the atrial fibrillation, there is an entity called paroxysmal atrial fibrillation where there are times where the patient is in atrial fibrillation and then reverts to sinus rhythm without intervention. Sometimes, people don't feel when they are in atrial fibrillation versus sinus rhythm and if the atrial fibrillation episode lasts more than 48 hours, then there is a higher risk for having a stroke. Usually, these patients are started on blood thinners to prevent strokes. If you are not sure how often and how long you are in atrial fibrillation then the best thing is to be started on blood thinners.   Atrial fibrillation causes embolization and one of the manifestations of embolization is getting a stroke but there are other manifestations for embolization such as having gangene of the legs or of the gut. author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Tachycardia
content: Dear Markos,  The first episode of tachycardia and hypertension was most probably related to all the stimulants that you took on that night.  For this new tachycardia, i would recommend that you stop all stimulants that you might be taking including coffee, tea, pop, anything that contains caffeine. You have to stop drinking any amount of alcohol and smoking any number of cigarettes.  Did you have blood tests when you went to the hospital the first time such as electrolytes in the blood? How about a thyroid function blood test?  You have to have a good night sleep. You have to have enough rest and stay away from stress.  If after all this, you still have the palpitations, i would suggest that you have a 24 hours heart monitor that will help to determine what is the rhythm that you have when you become tachycardic.  Concor is a beta blocker, it lowers both the blood pressure and the heart rate. What is the strength of the tablet that you are taking? The side effects that you are describing are most probably related to the concor.  Concor and all of the beta blocker group should never be stopped suddenly for any reason unless you discuss it with your doctor and has to be gradually weaned off of it.  There are other medications that can lower the blood pressure and the heart rate at the same time, this is the calcium channel blockers group. If the concor is giving you such hard time, i would suggest that you discuss switching to a medication that belongs to this group with your doctor.  Palpitations in young patients might point to a heart condition called mitral valve prolapse which is diagonsed by having an echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) and only needs to be watched. So, i recommend that you have an ultrasound of the heart.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: i am very upset with my cardiologists
content: Dear Lauren,  i don' t think that there have been enough big studies yet to say which way to go in which patients.  But, patients who develop peripartum cardiomyopathy and have persistent left ventricle dysfunction, are at a very high risk of complication during pregnancy and even death as pregnancy and labor pose a very high burden on the heart and circulation to begin with and these patients actually develop further reduction in their ejection fraction during pregnancy which means that their condition becomes worse. So, these patients are strongly advised not to become pregnant.   About patients whose ejection fraction improves, it was found in a small study that around 50% of these patients have deterioration in their ejection fraction during subsequent pregnancies and developed heart failure but there were no deaths reported.  i am not aware to which group of the above two you belong because i don't have this information, but there is no need to be upset or angry, i think you can always have a second opinion at a bigger tertiary care referral center.  If you belong to the second group and you were seen by a cardiologist who thought that you might become pregnant and all the risks that pregnancy to you and to your baby were discussed and you agreed to become pregnant, you have to understand that it is not going to be an easy process and that you will have to be watched very closely and carefully by obstetricicans with expertise in high risk pregnancy and cardiologists who have managed pregnant patients with peripartum cardiomyopathy before. And if you live in a smallish kind of town, it is not going to be easy commuting back and forth. You have to think about everything in advance and put everything into consideration before you chose to have this huge step as every detail will help you pass through pregnancy safely hopefully. content: Hi turtlesti, Your heart rate does slow down when you sleep because it requires less effort since your body processes are resting. content: Dear justwinbaby8,  Skipped beats are nothing to worry about in otherwise healthy young adult.  Palpitations or one feeling his/her heart beats can be caused by: 1. content: Dear Penny,  Thank you very much for the update.  In my personal opinion, if you just had sinus tachycardia, i don't think that you need to be treated unless you have coronary disease and your pulse should be controlled.   To diagnose hypertension, an elevated blood pressure should be found on more than 2 occasions during the same week. If during three different occasions (not the same day), high blood pressure is found, then this needs to be treated.  Atenolol is also used to control high blood pressure.   i can not tell you not to take the medication that your doctor prescribed, but you have to discuss it with your doctor if you think you don't want to take the medication because you don't need it or are concerned about side effects. title: Re: Idiopathic ventricular tachycardia
content: Dear Kev,  There are several types of ventricular tachycardia and some of them have causes and some of them don't.  i am not sure about the type of ventricular tachycardia you have. But it sounds from your story that this is a case of idiopathic ventricular tachycardia.  There are at least three types of ventricular tachycardia and i don't know which type you have. But two of them can be trigerred by exercise, how much exercise, i can not tell. Whether heavy lifting can trigger, i suppose it can, so, i would recommend not do heavy lifting like weight lifting at this time. About drinking alcohol and smoking, it is recommended that you abstain completely.  Since you are still symptomatic and you are young and it is not easy to live such a life with lots of restrictions, i would recommend you going to a cardiologist specialized in arrhythmias called an electrophysiolgist to have an electrophysiolgical study to try and locate the origin of this ventricular tachycardia and may be ablate it and get rid of the ventricular tachycardia. author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Unsure of diagnosis
content: Dear Mike,  It looks like you were not taking any medications that could affect your heart rate.   Are you an athlete? Do you perform heavy and strenuous regular exercise? What was your heart rate both resting and during exercise before all that started to happen? How long have you had these symptoms?  i think a thyroid function test called tsh should be performed if not already done as an underactive thyroid gland is well known to cause bradycardia.  It looks like they ruled out the major causes of bradycardia. Stress test, echo and ct scan were done.    One thing to add. Even though i don't think that this is the case, the granulomas in your lungs together with bradycardia could be caused by a disease called sarcoidosis that affects the lungs and heart. But it should have been picked up by the ct scan and the echo, so it was ruled out as well.  Since no other abnormality was detected and you are still symptomatic, i guess that you are having the begining of early degeneration of the electrical and conducting system of your heart. i think the next best step to do is to see a cardiologist specialized in the electrical and conducting system of the heart called an electrophysiologist. If he thinks it is necessary, he will conduct an electrophysiologic study of your heart to study the electrical and conducting system of your heart and then decide whether you need treatment or not. In such cases, treatment is a pacemaker.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: Inappropriate Sinus Tachycardia
content: Inappropriate Sinus Tachycardia (resting HR 110-135), peaking to 170+ with limited activity, accompanied by shortness of breath, chest pressure/pain, palpaltations, fatigue, and not responding to beta blocker (50mg).  Beta Blocker at this dosage drops blood pressure to below 95/65 and cannot be increased but has not had any major impact on heart rate. (For a short period, lowered peak from 170 to 140 but resting rate is now usually over 130).  Also, Beta Blocker has resulted in lower pulse pressure (often <20), resulting in lightheadedness, dizziness and near fainting.  24-Hr. Holter showed sinus tachycardia throughout.  Stress test 1 year ago showed downsloping ST Depression.  Angiogram 1 year ago revealed nothing of significance (40%).  All other causes of Tachycardia have been ruled out.  Question is:  Is this a benign condition (apart from the serious quality of life issue that has developed)?  Have had differing opinions with regard to this.  I have been told by one physician that only "rarely" does this result in cardiomyopathy and is benign otherwise.  Have been told by another that it is not a "benign condition" and "can" result in "damage" to the heart muscle.  So, just asking for a third opinion here.   Regards.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Inappropriate sinus tachycardia
content: Dear Fearuvhorses,  i don't want to ask you, were you checked for such and such because you were clear about having everything that can cause tachycardia checked. i hope that you are not drinking too much coffee, tea or alcoholic beverages. You can also take a look at my previous replies to your questions if you have not already done so.  This also can be a condition called postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome which is usually associated with chronic fatigue.   Have you had an echocardiogram? Ever seen a cardiologist for this tachyacrdia? There is an arrythmia called sinus node re-entry tachycardia that can look exactly like sinus tachycardia.   There are medications that can slow the heart rate and not affect the blood pressure like digoxin and amiodarone.   Tachycardia on the long run can cause cardiomyapthy but this is more related to ectopic atrial tachycardia and ventricular tachycardia and not sinus tachycardia.  At this point, if you have not seen a cardiologist specialized in arrhytmias, my advice is to do so and have a specialized study called electrophysiologic study (e.p.s.) to see whether this is truly sinus tachycardia or if it is another supraventricular arrhythmia disguising as sinus tachycardia.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
